The '''Big Inch''' and '''Little Big Inch''', collectively known as the '''Inch pipelines''', are [[petroleum]] [[Pipeline transport|pipelines]] extending from [[Texas]] to [[New Jersey]], built between 1942 and 1944 as emergency war measures in the U.S. Before [[World War II]], petroleum products were transported from the oil fields of Texas to the north-eastern states by [[oil tanker]]. After the United States entered the war on 1 January 1942, this vital link was attacked by German [[U-boat|submarines]] in the [[Second Happy Time|Operation Paukenschlag]], threatening both the oil supplies to the north-east and its onward [[transshipment]] to Great Britain. The [[United States Secretary of the Interior|Secretary of the Interior]], [[Harold L. Ickes|Harold Ickes]], championed the pipeline project as a way of transporting petroleum by the more-secure, interior route.
The pipelines were government financed and owned, but were built and operated by the War Emergency Pipelines company, a non-profit corporation backed by a consortium of the largest American oil companies. It was the longest, biggest and heaviest project of its type then undertaken; the Big and Little Big Inch pipelines were {{convert|1,254|and|1,475|mi|km|abbr=off}} long respectively, with 35 [[pumping station]]s along their routes. The project required 16,000 people and {{convert|725,000|ST}} of materials. It was praised as an example of private-public sector cooperation and featured extensively in US government [[propaganda]].
After the end of the war there were extended arguments over how the pipelines should be used. In 1947, the [[Texas Eastern Pipeline|Texas East Transmission Corporation]] purchased the pipelines for $143,127,000, the largest post-war disposal of war-surplus property. The corporation converted them to transport [[natural gas]], transforming the energy market in the north-east. The Little Big Inch was returned to carry oil in 1957. The pipelines are owned by Spectra Energy Partners and [[Enterprise Products]] and remain in use.
==Background== [[File:Oil goes to war. Be sure to see. In the battle too. Thrilling shots of planes in action. Battleships. Tanks^ - NARA - 534852.tif|thumb|upright|Poster advertising the importance of oil to the United States war effort]] By the time that the United States entered [[World War II]] in 1941, oil was a vital part of military operations around the world.<ref>{{harvnb|Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation|2000|p=2}}</ref> The United States produced 60 percent of the world's [[crude oil]], with the state of [[Texas]] in the south-west leading this production, producing more than twice as much crude as any other state.<ref>{{harvnb|Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation|2000|p=19}}; {{harvnb|Olien|Olien|2002|p=219}}</ref> The industry comprised a handful of very large producers and more than 3,500 smaller operators.<ref>{{harvnb|Olien|Olien|2002|pp=220–221}}</ref>
The north-east coast of the United States depended on these supplies of oil, importing both crude and [[Refined oil products|refined]] products.<ref name="Klein 2013 497">{{harvnb|Klein|2013|p=497}}</ref> Across most of Texas, there had been little interest in building pipelines to transport oil, and petroleum was typically moved from the south-west to the north-east coast using a mixture of sea freight and [[railroad]] transport.<ref>{{harvnb|Klein|2013|p=498}}; {{harvnb|Olien|Olien|2002|p=221}}</ref> In early 1941, 70,000 barrels of oil were moved on the railroads each day, but this method was expensive, and the bulk of the oil was moved using [[barge]]s, some with a capacity of up to 15,000 barrels, operating up and down the rivers and the [[East Coast of the United States|Atlantic Coast]].<ref name="Klein 2013 498">{{harvnb|Klein|2013|p=498}}</ref>
With the outbreak of war, the eastern sea routes of the country were attacked by German [[U-boat]] submarines.<ref name="Klein 2013 497"/> United States naval defence was very limited and largely obsolete; between January and April 1942, among other naval losses, 46 [[oil tanker]]s were sunk and 16 damaged.<ref>{{harvnb|Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation|2000|pp=6–7}}</ref> The problem was made worse as 50 tankers had been sent to help the UK earlier in 1941.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=9}}</ref> Insurers began to refuse to underwrite the remaining vessels and the volume of crude oil reaching the north-east from the Texas Gulf dropped.<ref name="Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation 2000 9">{{harvnb|Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation|2000|p=9}}</ref>
In response, steps were taken to better protect the tankers from attack, but losses continued to mount until, in April 1942, they were banned by the [[United States Navy|Navy]] from operating the north-east sea routes.<ref name="Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation 2000 9"/> The government and industry took steps to maximise the use of the railroads, increasing the amount of oil carried on them more than ten-fold, but there were shortages of rail [[tank car]]s, and the existing fleet of cars was in poor condition.<ref name="Klein 2013 498"/> Instead, the United States government began to examine options for the use of pipelines to fulfil the demand for petroleum in the north-east.<ref name="Klein 2013 498"/>
==Concept== [[File:Big Inch pipes on railroad tracks.jpg|thumb|Big Inch pipes stacked on a railroad, February 1943]] Transporting petroleum by pipeline from the south-west to the north-east was a potentially attractive option for the government as it would be safe from submarine attack and could operate efficiently regardless of the weather.<ref>{{harvnb|Klein|2013|p=499}}</ref> Pipelines had been in use in the industry since 1862, but by the 1930s they were usually only {{convert|8|in}} wide, able to deliver 20,000 barrels of oil a day; larger pipes could be built, but due to structural weaknesses they could not operate at the regular pressures.<ref>{{harvnb|Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation|2000|pp=10, 12}}</ref> Technologies to build high-pressure pipes at sizes larger than {{convert|12|in}} began to emerge during the decade before the war, but their adoption was not commercially viable.<ref>{{harvnb|Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation|2000|p=12}}</ref>
The concept of constructing such a pipeline was first proposed in 1940 by the [[United States Secretary of the Interior|Secretary of the Interior]], [[Harold L. Ickes|Harold Ickes]], who argued that "the building of a crude oil pipeline from Texas to the East might not be economically sound; but that in the event of an emergency it might be absolutely necessary".<ref>{{harvnb|Klein|2013|pp=498–499}}; {{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|pp=5–6}}</ref> A consortium led by [[Standard Oil Company of New Jersey|Standard Oil]] put forward a bid to build one in spring 1941, but the plan failed, due to concerns over the amount of steel that would be required for such a project.<ref>{{harvnb|Klein|2013|pp=498–499}}</ref> In May 1941, Ickes was appointed as the Petroleum Coordinator for National Defense, and in December 1942 became the administrator of the Petroleum Administration for War.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=6}}</ref> New laws were passed to enable the building of pipelines necessary for the war effort, including the compulsory purchasing of land under the right of [[eminent domain]].<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
Initial planning for the Inch pipelines began on May 15, 1941, when a meeting of Ickes and the oil industry commissioned an aerial survey of the possible route.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> A preliminary design was ready that September, and a consortium of major oil companies formed a new company, National Defense Pipelines, to build a pipeline along the route.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> The government [[Supply Priorities and Allocation Board]], however, refused to approve the necessary steel, and the consortium's plan was dissolved shortly before the outbreak of war.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> After the outbreak of fighting, and the consequent deterioration of the sea routes for transporting oil, industry representatives met in March 1942 to produce a new pipeline strategy, called the Tulsa Plan.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=7}}</ref> This included the construction of the Inch pipelines, backed by the slogan "longlines are lifelines", for which the steel was finally approved by the War Production Board on June 10.<ref>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=7}}; {{harvnb|Hyman|1998|p=228}}</ref>
Once steel supplies had been agreed, an initial [[tranche]] of $35 million in funding was provided by the government [[Reconstruction Finance Corporation]], which owned and manage the operation of the pipelines through its subsidiary organizations, the Defense Plants and the Defense Supplies corporations.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> In turn, the actual construction and operation of the pipelines would be carried out by the War Emergency Pipelines company (WEP), a non-profit corporation backed by a consortium of the largest oil companies in the United States: [[Atlantic Petroleum|Atlantic Refining]], [[Citgo|Cities Service Oil]], Consolidated Oil, [[Gulf Oil Corporation|Gulf Oil]], [[Pan American Petroleum and Transportation Company|Pan American Petroleum and Transportation]], [[Standard Oil]], [[Tidewater Petroleum|Tidewater Associated Oil]], [[Shell Oil Company|Shell Oil]], [[Socony-Vacuum Oil Company|Socony-Vacuum Oil]], [[Sun Oil Company|Sun Oil]] and the Texas Pipe Line Company.<ref>{{harvnb|Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation |2000|p=16}}; {{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|pp=7–8}}</ref> The WEP was led by [[W. Alton Jones]] and Burt Hull, both with extensive backgrounds in the industry, with Oscar Wolfe as its chief engineer.<ref name=Casella1999PP8>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|pp=8–9}}</ref> The company established its offices in [[Little Rock, Arkansas|Little Rock]], [[Arkansas]].<ref name=Casella1999PP8/>
==Construction==
===Design and management=== [[File:First carload of 24-inch seamless pipe for the Big Inch.jpg|thumb|220px|First carload of {{convert|24|inch|adj=on}} seamless pipe for the Big Inch]] The Inch pipelines comprised two systems, the Big Inch pipeline and the Little Big Inch pipeline.<ref name=Casella1999PP10>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|pp=10–11}}</ref> The Big Inch was a {{convert|24|in|mm|adj=on}} pipeline for crude oil; it ran from the [[East Texas Oil Field]] at [[Longview, Texas|Longview]], Texas, to [[Norris City, Illinois|Norris City]], [[Illinois]], and onto [[Phoenixville, Pennsylvania|Phoenixville]], Pennsylvania, from where it branched into {{convert|20|in|mm|adj=mid|-diameter}} segments.<ref name=Casella1999P10>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=10}}</ref> One served [[New York City|New York]] and terminated at [[Linden, New Jersey|Linden]], [[New Jersey]], and the other served [[Philadelphia]] and terminated at [[Chester Junction, Pennsylvania]].<ref name=Casella1999P10/> The Little Big Inch, a largely parallel {{convert|20|in|mm|adj=mid|-diameter}} line intended for refined products, ran from [[Beaumont, Texas|Beaumont]], Texas, to Little Rock, Arkansas, where it joined the path of the Big Inch, making use of the same [[pumping station]]s.<ref name=Casella1999P10/> From there it ran along the same right-of-way as the Big Inch to New Jersey and Pennsylvania.<ref>{{harvnb|Klein|2013|p=499}}; {{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|pp=10–11}}</ref>
The pipeline project was the longest, biggest and heaviest of its kind in the world.<ref name="Klein 2013 499">{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=13}}; {{harvnb|Klein|2013|p=499}}</ref> In total, the Big Inch pipeline was {{convert|1254|mi}} long, with {{convert|222|mi}} of secondary distribution and feeder lines, and had 28 pumping stations along the route, approximately every {{convert|50|mi}}.<ref name="Klein 2013 500">{{harvnb|Klein|2013|p=500}}; {{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|pp=10–11}}</ref> The Little Big Inch was {{convert|1475|mi}} long, with {{convert|239|mi}} of secondary lines, and had seven unique pumping stations along its southern leg.<ref name="Klein 2013 500"/>
Charles Cathers of the DPC directed the engineering project, with much of the work undertaken by Oscar Wolfe and, on the Little Inch pipeline, F. E. Richardson and L. F. Scherer.<ref>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|pp=9–10}}</ref> A meeting of all of the contractors for the build was held at the start of the July to kickstart the project; overall, 82 different companies would take on the pipeline work on a "cost-plus" basis, employing over 16,000 staff.<ref>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=12}}</ref> The construction required the government to acquire permission to build the pipeline across 7,500 parcels of land; of these, the right of eminent domain had to be exercised in 300 cases.<ref>{{harvnb|Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation|2000|p=19}}</ref> Major Jubel Parten, a director in the Petroleum Administration for War, considered the Inch pipelines to be part of “the most amazing Government-industry cooperation ever achieved”.<ref>{{harvnb|Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation|2000|p=15}}</ref>
The pipelines were soon given the names "Big Inch" and "Little Big Inch" by the construction teams, on account of their unprecedented diameters.<ref name="Klein 2013 499"/> The construction project was extensively advertised, as part of the US government's war-time propaganda effort.<ref name=Casella1999P18>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=18}}</ref> Newsreels ran clips such as ''Pipeline Goes Through!'' and ''Pipe Dream Comes True-Oil!'', and short-films were made about the construction work, including ''Pipeline''.<ref name=Casella1999P18/> The pipelines also appeared in the [[RKO Pictures|RKO Pathé]] film ''Oil is Blood''.<ref name=Casella1999P18/>
===Process=== [[File:Workers on the Big Inch pipeline.jpg|thumb|Workers on the Big Inch pipeline eating lunch, 1942]] The Big Inch pipeline was made from sections of seamless steel pipe up to {{convert|44|ft}} long, {{convert|3/8|in}} thick and {{convert|4200|lb}} in weight.<ref name=Casella1999P13>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=13}}</ref> The Little Big Inch used both {{convert|5/16|in}} thick seamless steel and electric weld pipe, and a small amount of {{convert|1/2|in}} thick seamless pipe.<ref name=Casella1999P13/> In total, 21,185 railcar loads of steel piping were laid during the project, the Big Inch alone requiring {{convert|360700|ST}} of steel.<ref name="Casella 1999 12–13">{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|pp=12–13}}</ref>
The pipe was laid in trenches {{convert|4|ft}} deep and {{convert|3|ft}} wide, dug out by a combination of ditching machines and manual labor.<ref>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|pp=13–14}}; {{harvnb|Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation|2000|p=19}}</ref> The pipes were then cleaned by pulling a workman through the inside of them with cloths, and welded together, using both the "stovepiping" method and the roll-weld, or "firing line", methods.<ref name=Casella1999PP13>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|pp=13–14}}</ref> Stovepiping was an older method, in which the welder worked his way around two pipes, which remained stationary; the newer roll-weld approach instead rotated the pipes, allowing the welder to remain in one position as he worked, with up to seven pipes being welded together at the same time.<ref>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=15}}</ref>
Where it was necessary for the pipeline to curve to fit the route, the steel pipes were bent, using either a cold-bending approach, in which tractors would pull and push the pipelines into position, or a hot-bending method, with the pipe heated up by [[blow-torch]]es and pulled into place using a [[Jig (tool)|jig]].<ref>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|pp=15–16}}</ref> A new, specialized piece of equipment for bending pipes, the Cummings bending jig, was invented during the Big Inch build, and used on the construction of the Little Big Inch pipeline.<ref name=Casella1999P16>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=16}}</ref> To protect the pipeline from corrosion, its outside was then cleaned by machine, and painted in first a layer of [[coal tar]] enamel, and then hot coal tar coating, before being wrapped in [[asbestos]] felt.<ref name=Casella1999P16/> Finally the pipeline was lowered into position, taking care not to damage the ends of the pipes; the larger pipes were so heavy that they required a [[Caterpillar D8|D-8 caterpillar tractor]] equipped with counter-weights to lift them.<ref>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|pp=13, 16}}</ref> The trench was then back-filled, completing the process.<ref name=Casella1999P16/>
The Big Inch pipeline had to pass under 33 rivers and 200 creeks and lakes, as well as under 289 railroad and 626 highway intersections.<ref>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=13}}; {{harvnb|Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation|2000|p=19}}</ref> Specially lined tunnels were bored to lay the pipe under the roads and railroad lines, and specialist trenches dug to lay the pipelines across on the riverbeds and lakes, weighing down the pipeline to stop it floating to the surface.<ref name=Casella1999PP13/> Around {{convert|4|mi}} of underwater piping was laid in total.<ref name=Casella1999P14>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=14}}</ref> In marshy areas, the soft ground was filled in to provide firm foundations for the pipeline to rest on.<ref name=Casella1999P14/>
The pumping stations for the pipelines were built on parcels of land between {{convert|11|acre}} and {{convert|44|acre}} in size; those with storage tanks were between {{convert|90|acre}} and {{convert|131|acre}} big.<ref name="Casella 1999 3">{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=3}}</ref> The plain, utilitarian buildings were initially prefabricated steel constructs, but as supplies grew scarce, wood was used instead.<ref>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=5}}</ref> As much as {{convert|725000|ST}} of materials was needed for the total project.<ref name="Casella 1999 12–13"/>
===Completion=== [[File:“Big Inch” opening.jpg|thumb|Ralph K. Davis, George Hull, [[W. Alton Jones]], and Burt Hull at the official opening, February 19, 1943]] Work on the Inch pipelines began immediately after the establishment of the WEP on June 26, 1942.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> They were built in three phases.<ref name=Casella1999PP10/> The first part to be constructed was the Big Inch, its initial leg running to an interim terminal at Norris City, where oil was to be off-loaded to the railroad network.<ref name=Casella1999P10/> Once this leg was complete, it was extended to its terminus at Phoenixville.<ref name=Casella1999P10/> When the Big Inch was complete, work began on the third phase of the project, the Little Big Inch.<ref name=Casella1999PP10/>
The first purchase order, for {{convert|137500|ST}} of 24-inch-diameter pipe, was placed on July 2, 1942. To meet a construction deadline of January 1, 1943, the laying of pipe began on August 3, 1942, near Little Rock. Other pipeline crews began work immediately on segments elsewhere in Arkansas and Texas. By September 10 all eight pipelaying crews, each consisting of between 300 and 400 men, were in the field working. The schedule called for {{convert|5|mi}} of the Big Inch pipeline to be laid each day. But soon men were laying as much as {{convert|9|mi}} a day. In all, roughly {{convert|7000000|yd3}} of material were excavated. Oil began flowing through the Big Inch Line between Texas and Illinois on New Year's Eve 1942.<ref>{{harvnb|Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation|2000|p=30}}</ref> Work on the Little Big Inch then began in 1943.<ref>{{harvnb|Waples|2012|p=173}}</ref>
The first crude oil arrived at Phoenixville via the Big Inch on August 14, 1943, and the first refined product in the Little Big Inch arrived on March 2, 1944. The Big Inch carried up to 334,456 barrels of crude oil a day, the Little Big Inch 239,844 barrels of gasoline; the lines were among the largest industrial consumers of electricity in the US, requiring 3.89 million kilowatt hours a day to pump the oil along the pipes.<ref>{{harvnb|Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation |2000|p=41}}; {{harvnb|Klein|2013|p=500}}</ref>

==Post-war sale== [[File:Big Inch Chambersburg building.jpg|thumb|[[Pumping station]] building near [[Chambersburg, Pennsylvania|Chambersburg]], [[Pennsylvania]], in 2014]] By the end of the war, there was considerable debate over the future of the pipelines.<ref name=Castaneda1993P68>{{harvnb|Castaneda|1993|p=68}}</ref> The major oil companies, such as Standard Oil, campaigned for the conversion of the pipelines for the transfer of [[natural gas]].<ref name="Castaneda 1993 68">{{harvnb|Castaneda|1993|p=68}}; {{harvnb|Waples|2012|p=173}}</ref> Demand for natural gas was rising rapidly, and it was produced in large quantities in the Texas oilfields, but could not be got to market in the north-east and was otherwise [[Gas flare|burnt off]] uselessly into the atmosphere.<ref name="Castaneda 1993 68"/> The railroad and [[coal]] companies, who saw this as likely to introduce additional competition for coal and [[coal gas]], and therefore lower demand for their goods and services, argued against this move.<ref name="Castaneda 1993 68"/> The smaller oil companies proposed continuing to use the pipelines for oil in order to undermine the transport monopolies of the larger corporations.<ref name=Castaneda1993P68/>
A government inquiry was undertaken to determine the future use of the pipelines, and took evidence from the various stakeholders, most of whom presented the case that favored their companies or industry.<ref>{{harvnb|Castaneda|1993|pp=69–74}}</ref> The inquiry concluded that the pipelines should be sold for continued use in transporting petroleum.<ref>{{harvnb|Castaneda|1993|p=74}}</ref> An auction for the pipelines was announced in 1946, which was designed to give preference to bidders who intended to use them for moving petroleum.<ref>{{harvnb|Castaneda|1993|p=76}}</ref> 16 bids were received, with the highest cash bidders being companies hoping to use the pipelines for natural gas.<ref>{{harvnb|Castaneda|1993|p=77}}</ref> Assessing the different bids proved difficult and the discussions became enmeshed in national politics, with companies seeking support from various Washington politicians.<ref>{{harvnb|Castaneda|1993|pp=76–82}}</ref> Meanwhile, a threatened national coal strike raised concerns over the availability of natural gas, strengthening the arguments of the natural gas lobby.<ref>{{harvnb|Castaneda|1993|p=83}}</ref>
A fresh inquiry was declared in November, voiding the previous competition and the Inch Lines were transferred to the [[War Assets Administration]] on December 2, 1946, for disposal.<ref>{{harvnb|Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation |2000|p=41}}; {{harvnb|Castaneda|1993|p=84}}</ref> Pending any final decision on their sale, the lines were leased to the [[Tennessee Gas Transmission Company|Tennessee Gas Company]] for use in shipping natural gas as far as Ohio and the Appalachians, but no further east, and only for 12 months.<ref>{{harvnb|Castaneda|1993|pp=85–86}}; {{harvnb|Nersesian|2010|p=240}}</ref> Tennessee Gas did not convert the pipelines in any way for their new role, and simply pumped the gas through the system under its own pressure, moving {{convert|138000000|cuft}} of gas a day in this way.<ref name="Casella 1999 24">{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=24}}</ref>
A second auction was held, with bids for natural gas given equal weight to those wishing to transfer crude oil, although any natural gas bidder would be obliged to maintain the oil pumping stations for use in a national emergency.<ref>{{harvnb|Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation |2000|p=42}}; {{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|pp=21–22}}</ref> Ten bids were received and on February 8, 1947, the [[Texas Eastern Pipeline|Texas East Transmission Corporation]] (TETCO) was declared successful.<ref>{{harvnb|Castaneda|1993|p=91}}</ref> Its bid of $143,127,000 would make the disposal the largest sale of war-surplus property to the private sector following World War II.<ref>{{cite web|title=BIG INCH AND LITTLE BIG INCH|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/dob08| last1 =Palmer | first1=Jerrell Dean | last2 =Johnson | first2=John G. |date = June 12, 2010 | website = [[Handbook of Texas|Handbook of Texas Online]]| publisher=Texas State Historical Association | accessdate=March 31, 2013}}; {{harvnb|Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation |2000|p=42}}; {{harvnb|Castaneda|1993|p=91}}</ref>
==Conversion by TETCO== [[File:Big and Little Inch pipelines map.png|thumb|300px|Map of the Inch pipelines: yellow - Big Inch, green - Little Inch; circles - pumping stations; rectangles - storage tank farms]] TETCO was the brainchild of corporate lawyers Charles Francis and [[James A. Elkins|James Elkins]], who convinced the construction specialists [[George R. Brown|George]] and [[Herman Brown]], and the fuel engineer E. Holley Poe, that buying the Big and Little Inch pipelines could be a lucrative opportunity.<ref>{{harvnb|Hyman|1998|pp=228–229}}</ref> The corporation was established specifically for the purposes of the bid, and came to their bidding figure by estimating that the likely competition would bid at $130 million; their own figure exceeded this by 10 percent, and added on $127,000 to avoid a suspiciously round number.<ref name=Casella1999P22>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=22}}</ref> TETCO believed it could afford to make this offer because it intended to reuse the [[electric motor]]s in the oil pumping mechanisms for moving the natural gas; it also believed that the price of gas would rise considerably in the post-war markets.<ref>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|pp=21–22}}</ref>
After winning the bidding, TETCO raised the money to pay the government through a combination of [[Bond (finance)|bonds]] and [[Share (finance)|share]] issues.<ref name=Casella1999P22/> A further government enquiry was required before the sale was allowed to go through, which was complicated by the reluctance of the state of Pennsylvania to allow the pipelines to be used to pump gas east through its territory.<ref>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=23}}</ref> The government of Pennsylvania was influenced by the coal industry, who feared they would lose sales, but it eventually relented and the sale of the pipelines to TETCO was finally completed on November 1.<ref>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=23}}; {{harvnb|Waples|2012|p=173}}</ref> The value of the company soared, and the original investors saw the value of their holdings increase 63-fold.<ref>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=22}}; {{harvnb|Hyman|1998|p=233}}</ref>
TETCO immediately began to convert the pipelines for permanent use as natural gas transmission lines, under the direction of Baxter Goodrich, their chief engineer.<ref name="Casella 1999 24"/> 24 [[compressor station]]s were constructed along the pipeline with [[centrifugal compressor]]s, increasing the capacity of the system to {{convert|433000000|cuft}} of gas a day, and the old oil pumps were retained for reuse in a future crisis.<ref name=Casella1999P25>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=25}}</ref> Steel valves replaced the older, less reliable [[cast iron]] designs.<ref name=Casella1999P25/> Demand continued to increase, requiring additional compressor capability, and by January 1949 the pipelines were moving {{convert|508000000|cuft}} a day.<ref>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=26}}</ref>
The supply route undermined the local markets for manufactured gas, and the major cities of the north-east rapidly converted to the use of natural gas; historian David Waples describes how the pipelines contributed to "an extraordinary expansion of natural gas customers and gas company employees after World War II".<ref>{{harvnb|Nersesian|2010|pp=239–240}}; {{harvnb|Waples|2012|p=174}}</ref> The Inch pipelines encouraged the development of further long distance pipelines in the US through the 1960s and 1970s.<ref>{{harvnb|Vassiliou|2009|p=404}}</ref>
==Later use== [[File:Marx Big Inch Pipeline - Construction Camp Quonset Hut-004.JPG|thumb|1962 toy [[Quonset hut]], sold as part of the [[Louis Marx and Company|Marx]] "Big Inch pipeline" construction set]] In 1957, the operation of the Little Big Inch, and its ownership south of Ohio, was transferred from TETCO to the subsidiary [[TEPPCO Partners|Texas Eastern Petroleum Products Corporation]] (TEPPCO), and converted back to use for petroleum products.<ref>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|pp=3–4}}</ref> TEPPCO was purchased by [[Enterprise Products]] in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=ard4juLLQVU0|publisher=Bloomberg|title=Enterprise Products to Buy Teppco for $3.3 Billion|date=June 29, 2009|accessdate=March 7, 2015}}</ref> Around 1961, there was discussion of converting the Big Inch pipeline back to petroleum use, but it continued in use as a gas pipeline.<ref>{{harvnb|Locke|1961|p=240 }}</ref> In 1989, TETCO was taken over by the Panhandle Eastern Corporation, and in 1997 this company was merged with Duke Power, to form the Duke Energy Corporation; in 2007, the oil pipelines were spun off from Duke Energy, to form part of Spectra Energy Partners.<ref>{{cite web|title=History: Important Milestones in Our History|url=http://www.spectraenergy.com/About-Us/History/|publisher=Spectra Energy|accessdate=April 12, 2015}}</ref>
The Inch pipelines are listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]].<ref name="achp1">{{cite web|title=PA on Big Inch and Little Big Inch Pipelines|url=http://www.achp.gov/pipelinepa.html|publisher=Advisory Council on Historic Preservation|accessdate=March 31, 2014|year=2002}}</ref> Along the western parts of the pipelines, around 90 percent of the pipes are the original installation, although in the east large parts have since been replaced, largely due to the absence of anti-corrosion protective coatings on the original piping.<ref name=Casella1999P4>{{harvnb|Casella|Wuebber|1999|p=4}}</ref> 62 of the original buildings from 1942 and 1943 remain, including pump-houses, offices, employee houses and garages.<ref name="Casella 1999 3"/> The best surviving examples of the original buildings are in Pennsylvania.<ref name=Casella1999P4/> A "Big Inch pipeline" construction playset was produced as a children's toy in 1962 by the [[Louis Marx and Company|Marx]] company.<ref>{{harvnb|Vanderbilt|2005|pp=85–86}}</ref>
